▣ Night Court Comedy 8p
A revival of NBC's hit 1980s sitcom returns one of that show's stars, John Larroquette, who reprises his role of proscecutor Dan Fielding. Melissa Rauch ( The Big Bang Theory ) also stars as judge Abby Stone, a new character who is the daughter of the original show's judge (played then by the late Harry Anderson). Two episodes air back-to-back tonight.

▣ Godfather of Harlem Trailer Drama MGM+, 9p
The Forest Whitaker-led drama's third season debuts tonight in conjunction with the renaming of cable channel Epix to MGM+. Years from now, we'll all remember where we were the moment that Epix changed to MGM+.
▣ The Last of Us Trailer Drama 9p
Is this the best videogame adaptation in history? Early reviews are terrific for The Last of Us , which comes from Chernobyl creator Craig Mazin along with Neil Druckmann, the co-president of the game studio (Naughty Dog) that created the critically acclaimed PlayStation game franchise of the same name. Retaining the post-apocalyptic setting and many of the characters from those games but expanding the story, the nine-episode series follows the smuggler Joel (played by The Mandalorian 's Pedro Pascal) and Ellie, the orphaned teen girl in his care (Bella Ramsey, Game of Thrones ) as they attempt to escape from a quarantine zone and travel across the remains of the United States two decades after human civilization has been mostly wiped out by a fungal pandemic. Gabriel Luna, Anna Torv, Nick Offerman, Nico Parker, Murray Bartlett, and Melanie Lynskey also star, and some of them will be portraying new characters who were not in the games. (And a few voice actors from the game series, most notably Merle Dandrige, who plays Marlene, will also make the jump to the TV show.) Directors include Ali Abbasi ( Holy Spider ) and Jasmila Zbanic ( Quo Vadis, Aida? ) as well as Druckmann himself. HBO reportedly spent well over $100 million on the Canadian-filmed series, though you can probably pick up the games at Best Buy for far less.

▣ The Makanai: Cooking for the Maiko House Trailer Foreign/Drama
Accomplished Japanese film director Hirokazu Kore-eda, best known for his Cannes-winning film Shoplifters , detours into television for his first Netflix series. The Makanai is also the first live-action adaptation of the award-winning manga series Kiyo in Kyoto and, like the comics, will focus on a young woman who becomes a Makanai—one who cooks meals for a house shared by apprentice geishas (or Maiko). Kore-eda directs multiple episodes in addition to serving as writer and showrunner on the series.
The Makery Family Peacock

▣ The Traitors Trailer Reality competition Peacock
Alan Cumming hosts a British adaptation of a Dutch competition series that finds a mix of reality show veterans and fresh faces competing in a series of challenges to win a $250,000 grand prize. But three of the contestants will be a team of traitors who aim to steal the prize from the remaining group.
▣ Velma Trailer Animation/Comedy HBO Max
If you can think of only one Velma: Yes, it's that one. (If you can think of a second one, you might be in the wrong century.) Created by Charlie Grandy ( The Mindy Project , The Office ), HBO Max's newest adult animated comedy series depicts the high school origin story of Scooby-Doo character Velma Dinkley—"the unsung and underappreciated brains of the Scooby-Doo Mystery Inc. gang"—voiced here by Mindy Kaling. Also lending their voices to the 10-episode series are Glenn Howerton as Fred, Sam Richardson as Shaggy, and Constance Wu as Daphne, while guests include Jane Lynch, Stephen Root, Wanda Sykes, Yvonne Orji, Kulap Vilaysak, Nicole Byer, Cherry Jones, Melissa Fumero, Ken Leung, Ming-Na Wen, "Weird Al" Yankovic, and more. Just don't expect Scooby ... or a van. Two episodes arrive each week.

▣ The Exiles Documentary ($) Rent/Buy
In their Sundance-winning debut feature (which arrives as a straight-to-VOD release today, nearly a year later), directors Violet Columbus and Ben Klein follow documentary filmmaker Christine Choy as she travels with footage from an abandoned project she began in 1989 on the Tiananmen Square massacre to Taiwan, Maryland, and Paris in order to share it with three exiled dissidents who have never been able to return home.

▣ Koala Man Trailer Animation/Comedy
Adult Swim veteran Michael Cusack ( YOLO: Crystal Fantasy , Smiling Friends ) moves to Hulu for his latest adult animated series, which follows a middle-aged dad (voiced by Cusack) who moonlights as a relatively powerless superhero who dresses in a koala mask and seeks to snuff out petty crime in his small Australian town. Hugh Jackman (yes, the famous one), Sarah Snook, Jemaine Clement, and Demi Lardner also lend their voices to the eight-episode series, which counts Rick & Morty 's Justin Roiland and Detective Pikachu 's Benji Samit and Dan Hernandez among its producers.

▣ Mayfair Witches Trailer Drama AMC+
Rescheduled from January 5. AMC's latest Anne Rice adaptation (and there will be more) is based on the author's Lives of the Mayfair Witches series. The eight-episode series comes from Masters of Sex veterans Esta Spalding and Michelle Ashford and stars Alexandra Daddario as a neurosurgeon who discovers that she comes from a family of witches. Jack Huston, Tongayi Chirisa, and Harry Hamlin also star. The first two episodes stream today, followed by weekly installments. The premiere episode (but not any of the others yet, though they are likely to eventually end up on AMC) will also air on cable tonight at 9p on five different networks including AMC, Sundance, and BBC America.

▣ The Pale Blue Eye Trailer Thriller
Scott Cooper ( Crazy Heart ) directs a gothic crime thriller based on the novel of the same name by Louis Bayard. Set in the 1830s at West Point, the film finds a detective (Christian Bale) investigating a series of murders at the United States Military Academ with the help of a young cadet named Edgar Allan Poe (Harry Melling). Gillian Anderson, Lucy Boynton, Toby Jones, and Charlotte Gainsbourg also star.

▣ Copenhagen Cowboy Trailer Foreign/Drama
Redundantly described as "neon-drenched noir" in press materials—since when did director Nicolas Winding Refn make anything but that?—this Danish-language Netflix series is the second TV project from Refn, following his stylish but flabby 2019 Amazon drama Too Old to Die Young . It's also his first project set in his native country since his Pusher trilogy concluded in 2005, though the location is more a product of necessity (thanks, pandemic lockdown) than anything else. The six-episode series centers on a mysterious woman (Angela Bundalovic) who navigates Copenhagen's criminal underworld, and reviewers at the show's Venice premiere in September were again underwhelmed by a director who appears to have peaked with Drive over a decade ago—though, to be fair, only a few critics have reviewed Cowboy so far.

▣ Kaleidoscope Trailer Anthology/Drama

▣ Paul T. Goldman Trailer Comedy/Reality Peacock
Might it be time to start paying attention to Peacock? The first of several promising debuts this month for the previously underwhelming streaming service was a surprise reveal just a few weeks ago, but Paul T. Goldman has actually been in the works for a full decade—or so they say. But the line between truth and fiction is exceptionally blurry in a series that should appeal to fans of The Rehearsal and Borat . In fact, Goldman comes from Borat Subsequent Moviefilm director (and frequent Nathan Fielder collaborator) Jason Woliner, and his true-crime spoof (or is it?) follows the extraordinary circumstances that have ensnared real person Paul T. Goldman, a single dad whose new relationship may be part of a major scam, leading Goldman to write a book and then film a movie about his life. The latter, whose making is filmed by Woliner for this series, quickly goes off the rails as Goldman (who opts to star as himself!) begins changing the details about his life. Three episodes stream today with additional new episodes arriving over the next three Sundays.

▣ 1923 Trailer Drama Paramount+
The latest installment in Taylor Sheridan's Yellowstone Expanded Universe arrives almost exactly one year after the debut of the previous prequel, 1883 and, like that series, will be a streaming exclusive. We're going to guess that it's set roughly 40 years after the latter (but not in 1932, as the new series was originally titled, which means that it will take place during Montana's local economic downturn and not the nationwide Great Depression), and it will center on several additional generations of Duttons—including family members played by Harrison Ford (in his first regular TV role), Helen Mirren, Darren Mann, James Badge Dale, and Michelle Randolph. Non-Dutton regulars include a sheriff played by Robert Patrick and a wealthy and powerful local played by Timothy Dalton.

▣ Bardo, False Chronicle of a Handful of Truths Trailer Foreign/Comedy/Drama
Alejandro González Iñárritu's first film since 2015's The Revenant (and his first Mexico-set feature since Amores Perros over two decades ago) is a Spanish-language dramedy centering on a Mexican journalist and documentarian who returns to his native country from his new home in Los Angeles after winning a prestigious award, only to be thrown into an existential crisis. The film arrives on Netflix today after first debuting at Venice in September and opening in theaters on November 4. Note that the film has been re-edited and slimmed down since it received disappointing reviews at its Venice premiere (though Bardo is still a long movie at around 150 minutes).

▣ Nanny Trailer Horror/Thriller Prime Video
The winner of the top prize at this year's Sundance Film Festival, the feature debut from writer-director Nikyatu Jusu draws on West African folklore to tell the story of a Senegalese immigrant (Anna Diop) who leaves her own son behind (temporarily, she hopes) to find work in America, where she secures a job as a nanny for the young daughter of wealthy white Manhattanites. But her already difficult life becomes more so as a series of haunting dreams plagued by an ominous supernatural presence begin to blur into reality. The film will also play in theaters beginning November 23rd.

▣ Kindred Trailer Drama/Sci-fi
This FX-produced adaptation of Octavia Butler's influential 1979 novel Kindred comes from Branden Jacobs-Jenkins (a producer on Watchmen and Outer Range ). Newcomer Mallori Johnson heads the cast as Dana James, an aspiring writer who relocates to Los Angeles but then finds herself shifting back and forth through time between the present day and a 19th century plantation that played a major role in her family's history. Producers on the series include Darren Aronofsky and The Americans team of Joe Weisberg and Joel Fields, while directors include Janicza Bravo ( Zola ). All eight episodes are available to stream today.

▣ Emancipation Trailer Drama/Action/Thriller Apple TV+
Also playing in theaters (starting 12/2), actor Will Smith's first film since The Slap™ is a true-story-inspired historical drama in which Smith plays a brutally tortured but newly escaped slave who journeys to the North and joins the Union Army. Antoine Fuqua directs, while Ben Foster also stars. In a normal year, Emancipation likely would have been Apple's best chance at the Oscar best picture race, but did we mention The Slap™? Because of the presumed backlash following Smith's last (unscheduled) Oscar ceremony appearance, Apple weighed delaying the film into 2023, and by the time they finally made a decision, Emancipation had missed all of the key film festivals usually used to launch Oscar contenders.

▣ Willow Trailer Drama/Fantasy Disney+
A Lucasfilm-produced TV series sequel to Ron Howard's 1988 fantasy film of the same name , Willow finds Warwick Davis reprising his role as the title character, a dwarf sorcerer, in a story that takes place 20 years later. The cast is otherwise entirely new and includes Ruby Cruz (effectively the lead, as she plays the princess Kit who leads a rescue party to save her kidnapped twin brother), Ellie Bamber, Erin Kellyman, Christian Slater, and Tony Revolori. The TV adapation comes from Jonathan Kasdan, who also serves as showrunner alongside Wendy Maricle.

▣ The Kingdom Exodus Trailer Foreign/Drama/Horror MUBI
Rivalling only David Lynch's Twin Peaks (a clear influence) for its blend of supernatural horror, dark comedy, and out-and-out strangeness, Lars von Trier's Danish hospital TV series The Kingdom ran for two seasons in 1994 and 1997. (It was later remade in America by Stephen King, but not successfully.) But if Lynch could bring Peaks back for another round, why can't von Trier do the same with The Kingdom ? And so we have Exodus , a third (and said to be final) set of five episodes, all directed by von Trier and featuring a mix of old and new faces (including, respectively, Udo Kier and Alexander Skarsgard), with the latter group mostly replacements for actors who have died since the prior miniseries. This time, the director gets, well, "meta" as he opens the series with a woman angered by watching that previous Kingdom season and winds up entering the hellish hospital herself. Episodes stream weekly, and if you have yet to see the original two seasons, those hard-to-find episodes will also begin streaming on MUBI on November 13 (for season 1) and November 20 (for the second season).

▣ Echo 3 Trailer Drama Apple TV+
A 10-episode, bilingual action-thriller created by Oscar-winning screenwriter Mark Boal ( The Hurt Locker ) and adapted from an award-winning Israeli series called When Heroes Fly , Echo 3 centers on the disappearance of an American scientist (Jessica Ann Collins) near the border between Colombia and Venezuela. Attempting to track her down are her brother (Luke Evans) and husband (Michiel Huisman), each of whom have military experience but also complicated pasts. Three episodes stream today, followed by weekly single-episode installments on Fridays beginning December 2nd.

▣ Wednesday Trailer Clip Comedy/Horror
Netflix's new Addams Family spinoff series centering on the high school years of the now-teenaged Wednesday Addams (Jenna Ortega) comes from Smallville creators Alfred Gough and Miles Millar and finds Tim Burton directing half of the eight episodes—marking the latter's first TV work since a 1986 episode of Faerie Tale Theatre . Much of the action takes place at Wednesday's school, Nevermore Academy, where she will confront the supernatural mystery plaguing her family and attempt to stop a killing spree in the local town (in between homework assignments, presumably). Gwendoline Christie, Riki Lindhome, Jamie McShane, and Percy Hynes White also star, while Catherine Zeta-Jones and Luis Guzmán will recur as Morticia and Gomez Addams, respectively, while Fred Armisen plays Uncle Fester. Also appearing is Christina Ricci, who played Wednesday in a pair of 1990s Addams Family films but will be portraying a new character in the series.

▣ Welcome to Chippendales Trailer Drama
Kumail Nanjiani stars as Steve Banerjee, the Indian immigrant who founded the Chippendales male-stripping empire, in this eight-episode based-on-a-true-story limited series formerly titled Immigrant . Created by screenwriter Robert Siegel (who also created the recent Hulu miniseries Pam & Tommy ), Chippendales is not exactly your standard American Dream success story—among other things, it's described as a true crime saga and a dark comedy—but the show does feature a strong cast that also includes Murray Bartlett, Dan Stevens, Annaleigh Ashford, Robin De Jesús, Andrew Rannells, and Juliette Lewis. Jenni Konner ( Girls ) serves as showrunner alongside Siegel, while Matt Shakman ( WandaVision ) directs. Two episodes stream today.

▣ A Christmas Story Christmas Trailer Comedy/Drama/Family HBO Max
This sequel to the beloved 1983 holiday comedy A Christmas Story finds Ralphie (played once again by Peter Billingsley, who has spent most of the past few decades on the other side of the camera as a director and producer) returning to his childhood home with his own kids in tow. Also returning from the original film are Zack Ward, Scott Schwartz, Ian Petrella, and R.D. Robb, while new faces include Julie Hagerty (taking over as Ralphie's mom) and Erinn Hayes (as Ralphie's wife). It's technically the third sequel to the original film, though you'd be forgiven if you can't remember 1994's dud It Runs in the Family (aka My Summer Story ) or the straight-to-video 2012 sequel A Christmas Story 2 .

▣ The Calling Trailer Drama Peacock
David E. Kelley's newest crime series (titled The Missing until just a few months ago) is an adaptation of the novel The Missing File by Dror A. Mishani. The eight-episode series centers on an NYPD detective named Avraham Avraham (played by Unorthodox 's Jeff Wilbusch) who believes his spirituality gives him an edge in cracking cases. His beliefs, however, are put to the test when what begins as a routine investigation turns out to be anything but. Juliana Canfield ( Succession ), Karen Robinson, and Michael Mosley also star, while Barry Levinson directs today's opener and additional episodes.

▣ The Crown Trailer Drama
The fifth of what will eventually be six seasons of Netflix's hit Emmy-winning period drama about the life of Queen Elizabeth II brings another cast overhaul as the story jumps forward in time to the mid-1990s—and the eventual death of Princess Diana (now played by Elizabeth Debicki). Imelda Staunton takes over as the Queen, while Jonathan Pryce now plays Prince Philip, Lesley Manville is Princess Margaret, and Jonny Lee Miller portrays new Prime Minister John Major. Also starring this season, as then-Prince Charles and Camilla Parker Bowles, are Dominic West and Olivia Williams, respectively, while the former's real-life son Senan West plays Prince William as a teenager (though not until the end of the season).

▣ Dangerous Liaisons Trailer Drama Starz, 9p
The latest take on the 18th century French novel—a tale of romance and backstabbing which has been adapted multiple times in seemingly every medium imaginable, though this is the first English-language TV adaptation— depicts the romantic entanglements of members of the court of Louis VXI in 18th century Paris, and, in particular, the origin story of the complicated relationship between Merteuil (Alice Englert) and Valmont (Nicholas Denton). The reimagining comes from Harriet Warner ( Call the Midwife , Tell Me Your Secrets ) and also stars Leslie Manville, Paloma Faith, and Game of Thrones alumni Carice van Houten and Michael McElhatton.

▣ Weird: The Al Yankovic Story Trailer Comedy/Music The Roku Channel
Daniel Radcliffe stars as beloved musician and song parodist “Weird Al" Yankovic in a comedic, Funny or Die-produced biopic about Yankovic's music career and personal life—with only most of the facts changed. Yankovic himself co-wrote the script, making it his first film project since his 1989 cult classic UHF . Eric Appel ( Brooklyn Nine-Nine , Silicon Valley ) directs a cast that also includes Quinta Brunson (as Oprah Winfrey), Evan Rachel Wood (as Madonna), and Rainn Wilson (as legendary DJ Dr. Demento), while Toby Huss and Julianne Nicholson play Al's parents.

▣ Blockbuster Trailer Comedy
Inspired by the true story of the planet's sole remaining Blockbuster Video location (in Bend, Oregon)—also the subject of a recent documentary —Netflix's new sitcom is a single-camera workplace comedy set in the last Blockbuster standing. Randall Park stars as the store's manager, and he's joined there by Melissa Fumero, Madeleine Arthur, JB Smoove, Tyler Alvarez, Olga Merediz, and Kamaia Fairburn. The series comes from Superstore / Brooklyn Nine-Nine writer Vanessa Ramos and also counts David Caspe ( Happy Endings ) among its producers. Ten episodes stream today, but you'll need to return them within three days if you don't want to pay any late fees.

▣ Guillermo Del Toro's Cabinet of Curiosities Trailer Anthology/Drama/Horror
Originally ordered by Netflix in 2018 under the title 10 After Midnight , this episodic horror anthology comes from acclaimed filmmaker Guillermo Del Toro ( The Shape of Water , Pan's Labyrinth ), whose only previous live-action TV series is The Strain (though he also has the animated Trollhunters at Netflix). Del Toro himself developed the stories for two of the eight episodes (others are a mix of original concepts and adaptations of stories by H.P. Lovecraft and other authors), and though he isn't among the roster of directors on the series, a number of recognizable names are, including Ana Lily Amirpour ( A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night ), Jennifer Kent ( The Babadook ), Panos Cosmatos ( Mandy ), Vincenzo Natali ( Cube ), and Catherine Hardwicke ( Twilight ). Cast members include Andrew Lincoln, Peter Weller, Eric Andre, Rupert Grint, Nia Vardalos, David Hewlett, Essie Davis, Glynn Turman, F. Murray Abraham, Sofia Boutella, Steve Agee, Tim Blake Nelson, Kate Micucci, Charlyne Yi, and Crispin Glover. Note the unusual rollout for a Netflix series: Two new episodes will stream each day this week through Friday.

▣ The Peripheral Trailer Drama/Sci-fi Prime Video
Westworld creators Lisa Joy and Jonathan Nolan return with another sci-fi series, this time based on a William Gibson novel (and adapted by Scott B. Smith rather than Joy and Nolan, who merely produce). Finally emerging out of a four-year development period, The Peripheral stars Chloë Grace Moretz as Flynne Fisher, a woman struggling with an ill mother and a flailing career in a small rural town in near-future America who gets an unexpected opportunity to escape to a far more exciting life via an experimental new VR device. But is what happens in VR (including a shocking murder) merely a simulation, as she first thinks—or is it somehow real? Jack Reynor, Gary Carr, and Alexandra Billings also star. New episodes stream weekly, and there should be plenty of material for future seasons if necessary: Gibson's book is part of a trilogy.

▣ Let the Right One In Trailer Drama/Horror 10p
An adaptation of the acclaimed 2008 Swedish horror film (which itself was adapted from a novel and was also previously remade for American audiences as a 2010 Matt Reeves film ), this Showtime series stars Demián Bichir as the father of a 12-year-old girl (Madison Taylor Baez). In fact, he's been the father of a 12-year-old girl for roughly a decade: She's an unaging vampire, and he has assigned himself the task of keeping her well-supplied with human blood. Grace Gummer, Anika Noni Rose, Nick Stahl, and Kevin Carroll also star. The series adaptation comes from Andrew Hinderaker, a playwright and writer on another Showtime horror series, Penny Dreadful . Tonight's premiere (the first of 10 episodes) will also be available to stream early on Showtime apps beginning October 7.

Forever Queens Foreign/Reality
▣ Interview With the Vampire Trailer Drama 10p
A series adaptation of the Anne Rice novel that was previously turned into a 1994 movie , this Interview comes from Perry Mason 's Rolin Jones. Sam Reid stars as the vampire Lestat (the role played by Tom Cruise in the film), while Game of Thrones vet Jacob Anderson plays Louis (aka the Brad Pitt role), Eric Bogosian takes on the role of journalist Daniel Molloy (that was Christian Slater in the movie), and future Avatar sequels star Bailey Bass portrays Claudia (the Kirsten Dunst role). The Alan Taylor-directed first of eight episodes airs tonight, though AMC+ subscribers can stream the second episode as well today. Interview was just renewed for a second season, and you can expect many more Anne Rice adaptations in the future: AMC has acquired rights to 18 of the author's books (in the Mayfair Witches series in addition to the Vampire Chronicles franchise), so more series and films will follow under the guidance of Breaking Bad producer Mark Johnson at a rate of 1-2 new titles per year.

▣ Nothing Compares Trailer Documentary 10p
Belfast native Kathryn Ferguson heads south of the border to find the subject for her first feature-length documentary: Irish singer-songwriter Sinéad O'Connor, whose early pop stardom in the late 1980s gave way to increasing controversy and activism (as well as a more under-the-radar continuing music career). Nothing Compares focuses on the first half of that description: O'Connor's rise to fame following a difficult childhood and her first, often misunderstood, attempts to take on the establishment. The result divided critics a bit when Nothing Compares debuted at Sundance early this year, but reviews were positive overall. Subscribers can also stream the film a few days early (starting 9/30) on Showtime's apps.

▣ Andor Trailer Drama/Sci-fi Disney+
Rescheduled from August. Diego Luna returns as the Rebel Alliance pilot/intelligence agent Cassian Andor (whom he first portrayed in 2016's Rogue One ) in Disney's fourth live-action Star Wars television series. A prequel to that film set mostly five years earlier (though flashbacks will go even further back in time), the gritty spy thriller Andor traces its title character's evolution into a rebel leader and also returns Alan Tudyk as the voice of droid K-2SO, Genevieve O'Reilly as Mon Mothma, and Forest Whitaker as Saw Gerrera and also stars Adria Arjona, Stellan Skarsgard, Denise Gough, and Kyle Soller. Veteran screenwriter Tony Gilroy serves as creator and showrunner, while his fellow writers include Beau Willimon ( House of Cards ) and Stephen Schiff ( The Americans ) and directors include Toby Haynes ( Black Mirror ). Season 1 runs 12 episodes (streaming weekly, though you'll get three episodes today) and a second 12-episode season begins filming this fall.

▣ Reboot Trailer Comedy
Despite the title, it's not really another TV reboot. Instead, Reboot is the first new series from veteran writer/producer Steven Levitan since he co-created Modern Family in 2009. And the Hulu series centers on the Hulu reboot of a fictitious family sitcom ("Step Right Up") from the early 2000s—one that reunites the highly dysfunctional cast of the original series and forces them to deal with their unresolved issues. Keegan-Michael Key, Johnny Knoxville, and Judy Greer head a strong real-life cast that also includes Paul Reiser, Rachel Bloom, Krista Marie Yu, and Calum Worthy. ▣ Quantum Leap Trailer Drama 10p
One of just two new NBC shows this fall, Quantum Leap is a reboot of the beloved 1989-93 NBC series that originally starred Scott Bakula as Dr. Sam Beckett, who used an experimental time travel device to temporarily inhabit the bodies of various people throughout recent history, using each "leap" to correct a mistake. The new series actually continues the story and basic format and finds a new scientific team (including the new traveler, played by Raymond Lee, plus Caitlin Bassett, and Ernie Hudson, among others) restarting the project three decades later.

▣ Confess, Fletch Trailer Comedy ($) Rent/Buy
This reboot of the film "franchise" (really, just two films, and one is thoroughly forgettable ) that began with the classic 1985 Chevy Chase comedy Fletch —which, in turn, was based on Gregory Mcdonald's books—arrives after decades of false starts, including an aborted third Chevy Chase vehicle from Kevin Smith. Instead, Jon Hamm takes over as the titular mystery-solving, wisecracking L.A. Times reporter. Also opening in theaters today, the new film comes from director Greg Mottola ( Superbad ) and is adapted from the second book in the series by former Chuck writer Zev Borow. Hamm's Mad Men co-star John Slattery also appears, as do Kyle MacLachlan, Marcia Gay Harden, Roy Wood Jr., Eugene Mirman, Anna Osceola, and Annie Mumolo. Confess will also head to Showtime on October 28.

SUN / September 11
▣ American Gigolo Trailer Trailer2 Drama 9p
Jon Bernthal stars as Julian Kaye—a role first portrayed by Richard Gere—in Showtime's series adaptation of Paul Schrader's 1980 movie of the same name . Tracing a somewhat similar story but from a different time perspective, the eight-episode series follows the one-time male escort Kaye after he completes a 15-year prison sentence for a murder that he didn't commit. Now, he must attempt to rebuild his life and find out who put him behind bars and why. Gretchen Mol, Rosie O'Donnell, Leland Orser, Lizzie Brocheré, and Gabriel LaBelle also star, while Wayne Brady and Melora Walters guest. The TV adaptation, which has been in development since 2016, comes from David Hollander ( Heartland )—though he was removed as showrunner in April following a misconduct investigation—and is produced, like the film, by Jerry Bruckheimer. Tonight's premiere can also be streamed two days early (beginning 9/9) on Showtime apps.

▣ The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power Trailer Final trailer Drama/Fantasy Prime Video
Now debuting one day early with a two-episode premiere at 6p PT / 9p ET. What will likely be the most expensive TV series of all time—with a budget reportedly twice that for the entire LOTR film trilogy, though it does come with free two-day shipping—finally makes its debut after years of production. Filmed in New Zealand like Peter Jackson's movies, prequel series The Rings of Power is not directly adapted from J.R.R. Tolkien's books but instead depicts a brand new story set in the same world but taking place in the "Second Age," several millennia prior to the events of The Hobbit during a time in which the rings of power were forged by Sauron. Settings include the island kingdom of Númenor and the Elvish capital, Lindon. J.A. Bayona directs the first two episodes, while the remaining S1 episodes come from Wayne Che Yip and Charlotte Brandstrom. Those episodes will stream weekly (at 9pm PT on Thursdays) rather than all at once, and a second season (to be filmed in the UK) has already been ordered and will be dropped off behind the planter on your front porch sometime next year.

▣ Pantheon Trailer Sci-fi/Animation/Drama AMC+/HIDIVE
Daniel Dae Kim, Katie Chang, Paul Dano, Taylor Schilling, Rosemarie DeWitt, Aaron Eckhart, Scoot McNairy, Corey Stoll, Maude Apatow, Ron Livingston, and William Hurt (in what turned out to be his final performance completed before his death) are just some of the voices you'll hear in this animated drama adapted by Craig Silverstein ( Turn: Washington's Spies ) from a short story collection by noted sci-fi author Ken Liu. Centering on the concept of uploading human consciousness to the cloud—and, in particular, on a bullied teen girl who receives help from what appears to be her dead father— Pantheon has already been renewed for a second season and is expected to air at some point on cable's AMC in addition to streaming on AMC+. New episodes (eight in total) stream weekly.
